post_excerpt: Let's answer this quickly by saying that if you have no dependents of any kind, and you're not an important part of a business, then you probably don't need life insurance. However, many adults do have dependents of various kinds - young children, spouse, partner, elderly parents, relatives or perhaps disabled relatives - who are not able to earn their own living.

post_title: The End of UK Based Pension Schemes?
post_content:
[vc_row full_width="" parallax="" parallax_image="" lvca_dark_bg=""][vc_column width="1/1"][lvca_team style="style2" per_line="1"][lvca_team_member member_name="Martyn Davies and Matthew Arnold" member_position="Austen Morris Associates" member_details="Martyn Davies and Matthew Arnold are two extremely successful offshore financial advisers with a wealth of knowledge acquitted over the last two decades in the industry, with Martyn having worked for a number of years in South Africa and Dubai, while Matthew was based in China. They are both currently located in Manila and they now operate out of Austen Morris Associates, providing bespoke financial solutions to expatriate clients across the Asia region and beyond.
<label>If you would like to contact Martyn and Matthew form further investment advice, please contact them at: <strong>martyn.d@austenmorris.com</strong></label>" member_image="277701"][/lvca_team][vc_separator color="grey" align="align_center" style="" border_width="" el_width=""][vc_column_text]We are all seeing more and more bad news stories regarding UK-based pension schemes, which is particularly prevalent in the defined benefit, or final salary, sector. New schemes have now all but died out due to the huge pressure that their funding puts on a company’s overall financial position, which has been driven primarily by rising life expectancy and record low returns on capital.

The aggregate deficit of the 5,945 schemes eligible for the Pension Protection Fund, the “lifeboat” scheme, was estimated at £270bn at the end of April, with 4,804 schemes in deficit and 1,141 schemes in surplus. There will be a major inquiry considering radical solutions to one of the great problems of this age, and the government is now considering a radical plan for the British Steel scheme which, with 130,000 members, is one of the largest private sector plans in the UK.

The consultation raises the prospect of billions of pounds being slashed from the long-term liabilities of the fund, which would be achieved in part by switching the indexation of pension increases from the RPI inflation index to the usually lower CPI measure. The government has said it is not considering extending the proposal, needed to allow the British Steel pension cuts, beyond that scheme.

But Mr Field said: “We should be under no illusions that British Steel was a special case. 11m people have private-defined benefit pensions. More than 5,000 of the associated schemes are in deficit to the tune of £805bn, while the combined surpluses of other schemes is £4bn.” He added: “This will be a major inquiry… the inquiry will consider, amongst other things, radical solutions that could be more easily implemented if real returns on capital rise again.”

In its consultation document published this week, the Department for Work and Pensions said it was aware that a number of other employers with defined benefit schemes had concerns about the size of their liabilities and the possible impacts on their sustainability as a business.

If you do have a UK-based defined benefit pension as part of your personal asset portfolio, it would be well worth seeking out a qualified pension expert to perform a free no-obligation pension health check. This should include a full and complete analysis of your current pension situation, which in many cases will include a number of schemes, as well as accounting for any other assets you hold which you would see as part of your pension planning.

There are many options available out there that would enable you to secure your and your family’s future financial security, most of which are offered in a far less volatile arena than the current UK pension sector.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text]
